div1.p: Carter provides bibliographical references to Henry Rose Carter's published articles.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to James P. Leake, April 18, 1927
div1.opener:
Biographic
(early y.f. articles)
Surgeon J. P. Leake
Surgeon J. P. Leake
U.S.A., F. S
School of Hygiene & Public Health,
615 North Wolfe Street,
Baltimore, Maryland.
April 18, 1927.
Dear Jimmy:
div1.p:
Your letter of April 13th. would have been answered earlier had I not
been too sick to write. The “Guardian Devil” of the Carter family played
a much resented April Fool joke by giving me a bad set-back, since which
date I've been living (existing rather!) on soft diet and aromatic spirits
of ammonia and trying to do some work on the side. This latter bacause I
am far behind the schedule I set myself last fall and want to finish my work
on the book before hot weather at any cost.

In Re a reprint of Father's article in the New Orleans Medical Journal
of May 1900, I agree with you that it would be an excellent thing to have
one (or a photostat of one) for the contemplated exhibit of Americana in
medicine at the New York Academy of Medicine. Indeed, Dr. Frost--to whom
I showed myyour letter--agreed with me that there should be three of Father's
publications in this exhibit, as they were all planned to-gether and written
about the same time, although the one to which you allude was the first of
the lot. These three would be:

list.item:
1: A Note on the Interval between Infecting and Secondary Cases of Yellow
Fever from the Records of the Yellow Fever at Orwood and Taylor, Miss., in 1898
New Orleans Medical Journal, May 1900. Also Ann. Rept. Marine Hospt.
Service 1900.

2: Period of Incubation of Yellow Fever in Man. (Planned with (1) and (3)
and written about the same time--the trilogy forming a complete work).
Published in Medical Record Feb.-or-M--1901. Original manuscripts
deposited as a permanent loan at the Library of the Surgeon General of the
Army.

3: A Note on the Spread of Yellow Fever in Houses. Extrinsic Incubation.
Medical Record, June 15, 1901. Also in Ann. Rept. M. H. S. 1900 (Appeared in
print probably some time in 1901; certainly after Nov. 1900).

div1.p:
I am herein enclosing my only copy of # 3: (Extrinsic Incubation). I can
find no reprints of Nos. 1 and 2, but believe that you may find them (in addi-
tion to the original MSS) at the Library of the Surgeon General of the Army or
or-
-2-
possibly--at the Library of Congress. In either case one would have to
get photostats (as would be advisable with the reprint on Extrinsic In-
cubation, as I have no other copy). I don't know how much this would cost,
but if the Academy of Medicine (or the Service) can't arrange for this to
be done, I judge I can “swing” it. They charge about 15 cents a page for
photostats--don't they?

Dr. Frost thinks that you should also have a complete bibliography of
Father's writings on yellow fever. He compiled one last fall and we will
send you a carbon copy if one is available. If not, he will have one of
his secretaries make an extra copy for you. I shall also send you a re-
print of his article (read in Melbourne) on
The Chance of the Extension of Yellow Fever to
Asia and Australia. (1925?)
as these were not printed until long after the article was read and I have
not yet distributed them.

With dear love to Chase and the children and all sorts of good wishes
to you, each and every one.
div1.closer:
Most truly your friend, Laura A. Carter 1 enclosure.
Surgeon J. P. Leake,
U. S. Public Health Service,
16 Seventh Street, S. W.,
Washington, D. C.
